OCDS.description: Describe the question and answer session

nonOCDS.task: Describe the question and answer session
nonOCDS.prompt:
During the application period, you must respond to all questions suppliers have about your requirements. This should be done as soon as possible, ideally within 24 hours of receipt.

When to run a question and answer session


Providing a dedicated question and answer session means you can explain your needs and answer any questions quickly. This is useful if your requirements are complex and involve several stakeholders. You should aim to provide a session within a week of publishing your requirements.

You must specify what type of session you want to hold, when it will take place, and any other information that attendees will require:

  • the type of session you want to run, such as webinar, phone conference or meeting
  • the date and time of the session

Information you should include

Depending on the type of session you choose, you could also include:

  • software needed
  • a url
  • a phone number
  • an access code
  • an address (including postcode)

This list is not exhaustive; include anything else suppliers need to participate.

After the session, you must make the questions raised and your responses to them available to all suppliers.

OCDS.description: About assessment criteria and evaluation weightings

OCDS.title: About assessment criteria
OCDS.description:
You can only evaluate a supplier on any critieria you have included in the following sections. 
You will write a series of questions based on key themes:
technical criteria
social value criteria

You can group your questions into overall requirements for each set of criteria. 

You need to have a clear understanding of what you want to achieve in your project, including any outcomes and deliverables, before you write and publish these questions.

Your assessment criteria will help you to evaluate the capabilities of the suppliers equally. Your criteria must be relevant to the project, and the outcomes you want to achieve, and must not be written in a way that would disadvantage one supplier from another.

OCDS.title: About evaluation weightings
OCDS.description:
Instead of automatically accepting the lowest price quoted for the project, you will apply weightings for each of the main topics of questions, and for price, so you can find the best value for money.

The weightings can be used to ensure that you are clear about what is most important to your project and the outcomes you want from it. It will also help you identify the best supplier in terms of skills and capabilities, knowledge and if they meet your social value objectives.

If your project is very tehcnical, we recommend having a higer weighting for that set of criteria, so that you choose a supplier who best meets your needs.

Similarly, if your project is more about leading a team, you will want to place a higher weighting on the criteria that matches these needs.

nonOCDS.prompt:
Your assessment criteria will help you to make sure you are getting the best value for money, while fairly and compliantly evaluating suppliers.

About assessment criteria


You can only evaluate a supplier on the criteria you have included in your published requirements.

You will need to write individual questions under each of the evaluation categories. Depending on the service you are buying, these will include:
  • technical competence (the essential, nice-to-have and technical questions)
  • cultural fit
  • social value
You need to have a clear understanding of what you want to achieve in your project, including any outcomes and deliverables, before you write and publish these questions.

Decide on what the ‘essential’ and ‘nice-to-have’ skills and experience are so you can shortlist supplier responses later. The more specific you are with these questions, the easier it will be to find a supplier who meets your needs.

Your assessment criteria will help you to evaluate the capabilities of suppliers fairly. Your criteria must be relevant to the project and the outcomes you want to achieve. They must not be written in a way that favours one supplier over another.

About evaluation weightings

Instead of automatically accepting the lowest price quoted for the project, you will apply weightings to each of the question categories and to price in order to get the best value for money.

The weightings you enter will reflect what is most important to your project and the outcomes you want. Weightings can also identify the supplier with the best knowledge, skills, ability to meet your social value objectives, and cultural fit.

If your project is highly technical, it is advisable to give technical criteria a higher weighting. This will help you to choose a supplier who best meets your needs.

When you have simple requirements and know that many suppliers can meet them, price may be more important to you than technical competence.

If you need user research participants and your user research dates are fixed, availability may be more important to you than technical competence.

options.text: A fixed price approach can be more expensive because the supplier owns most of the risk. The approach works best when your requirements are well defined. This allows the supplier to provide an accurate quote without unnecessary costs. The supplier must complete all work specified in each 'statement of work' within the agreed time frame.

A time and materials approach means you own more of the risk. The supplier will charge you for the actual time worked by the supplied staff. The supplier can send a pricing matrix showing how long they need to provide the work. If the work takes longer than expected, you pay the day rate and expenses for extra days worked.

Unlike a time and materials approach, a capped time and materials approach limits the amount you pay for the work. If you reach the limit before the work is completed, the supplier must finish the work at their own expense. If the supplier finishes ahead of schedule, you only pay them for the time it took to complete the work.

nonOCDS.prompt: You should choose the pricing model that best fits the way you work and provides the best value for money.

Enter the number of suppliers you will take forward to the further assessment stage. You must evaluate at least 3 suppliers.

You should consider the complexity of your project, the resource you have available for evaluating suppliers, and your general procurement timelines.

OCDS.title: Create your scoring criteria
OCDS.description:
Select one of the two options below or enter the details for your own scoring criteria.

If you want to use the 4 or 5 level scoring criteria, select the option you want and then click 'save and continue'.

The minimum number of scoring levels is 2 and the maximum number of scoring levels is 10.

options.text: Create your own scoring criteria
Use the 4 level scoring criteria

cols: The response does not meet any of the requirements or no reponse has been provided. An unacceptable and / or non-compliant response with serious reservations, demonstrating no understanding of the requirement.

The response has met some, but not all elements of the requirement, which poses risk that the proposal will not meet the deliverables required.
The response does not demonstrate a full understanding of the requirement posing major concerns.

The response is acceptable and meets all the basic requirements. However, the response is not sufficiently detailed to minimise risk and / or the proposed approach may require additional support (in addition to that outlined in the Statement of Requirements) from the Contracting Authority to meet its deliverables.

The response exceeds requirements, providing detail that minimises risks to delivery. The response is comprehensive and unambiguous, demonstrating a thorough understanding of the requirements and providing details of how the requirement will be met in full without additional support from the Contracting Authority, other than that outlined within the Statement of Requirements.

OCDS.title: Enter the name for this level
OCDS.description: Use words that best reflect the scoring level, and that can be used alongside other criteria. For example ‘pass’ or ‘fail’, or ‘excellent’, ‘good’, ‘poor’.

OCDS.description: Make sure your scoring system does not overlap or cause confusion. Use whole numbers.

options.text: A presentation can help you understand a supplier’s approach to delivering work, for example, a practical demonstration of a prototype or discovery kick-off meeting.

A written reference can help you determine whether a supplier has completed the work they claim to have done. You should always ask for references that are pertinent to a specific timeframe, such as work they have done in the last 2 years.

An interview can help you assess whether a supplier has the necessary skills to work on your project. It will also allow you to determine whether they will be a good fit for your team.
You should follow a set format and ask all suppliers the same questions.

A scenario or test can help you confirm a supplier’s skill level and understanding in a controlled environment. For example, you could use a scenario to assess the approach a product manager would take to solve a problem, or carry out a coding test for a developer.

A case study is a good way to see, in detail, the work suppliers have done before. It can help you understand whether the people who’ll be working on your project have the right skills and experience.
A work history lists the previous work a supplier has done. It should give you a view of the skills and experience of the team members who will be working on your project.

nonOCDS.prompt:
All suppliers will have to provide a written proposal. It should be structured around the questions you want suppliers to answer.

You can also choose additional ways to assess suppliers.

You can only use the methods you choose here. For example, if you do not select presentation, you will be unable to hold supplier presentations.

OCDS.description: Which phase the project is in

options.text: You have not started any work on the project.

You still need to find out more about the problem that needs to be solved, including who the people who will use your service are and what they need the service to do, as well as any technology or policy constraints.

You have completed the discovery phase and are now testing solutions, usually by building prototypes and carrying out testing with real users. You are not yet in a position to release anything to the public.

You have established your best solution from the alpha phase, and now you are building it for real. At this stage, you are integrating your build with your existing systems and rolling it out to real users.
Your live service needs sustainable support, as well as iterations to improve and evolve.
Service design phases are not applicable to your project.

options.text: You outsource all ownership and responsibility for operational delivery to the supplier, including directing and managing the people delivering the service. You will not need to operate the off-payroll working rules but the supplier may.
options.value: Contracted out service: the off-payroll rules do not apply

options.text: You engage a person or team of people to work with your staff and you manage operational direction and control. The off-payroll working rules can apply to anyone who works through a qualifying intermediary such as their own limited company.
options.value: Supply of resource: the off-payroll rules may apply

nonOCDS.prompt:
As the buyer, you are the supplier’s client when buying a supply of resource (people to do the work).

This means that you are responsible for deciding if the off-payroll working rules (IR35) apply to them. You must meet your legal obligations where they do.

Choose whether you need a contracted out service or a supply of resource.
